newsitem.title: FRANCE: U.N.'s Annan says Iraq food shipments delayed.
newsitem.headline: U.N.'s Annan says Iraq food shipments delayed.

text.p: U.N. Secretary General Kofi Anna said on Saturday that the first deliveries of relief aid to Iraq under an oil-for-food deal would be delayed for 10 days.
"Unfortunately, there has been a little delay, but everything is going to begin in 10 days," Annan told reporters after talks with French President Jacques Chirac.
"I have just learned of this. I do not know the reasons for the delay," Annan said.
Under the oil-for-food programme, Iraq is permitted to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months to buy needed supplies for its people, who have suffered under trade sanctions since August 1990.
The complex deal involves U.N. monitors checking on food, medicine and other goods for the Iraqi people.
Annan, in for talks with French officials on a broad range of U.N.-related matters, had said on Thursday that the food deliveries to Iraq would begin on Saturday.
A Chirac aide said the French president had thanked Annan during their talks for the U.N. leader's work on the food-for-oil pact and reiterated his support for the programme.
The United Nations on Thursday named Staffan de Mistura, a veteran U.N. official for relief assistance in world troublespots, as the new coordinater for humanitarian aid in Iraq.
